div1.head: Military Orders for Valery Havard, William Crawford Gorgas, Jefferson Randolph Kean, and Rafael T. Echeverria, November 12, 1900
div1.p:
SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 266. }

HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, November 12, 1900.

FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Spec Orders Vol 2 1900
Havard--Gorgas--Kean--Echeverria

1. By direction of the Secretary of War, the unexecuted
portion of the sentence awarded by general court-martial to
Private Benjamin F. Childers, Troop C, 4th Cavalry, and pro-
mulgated in paragraph 4, Special Orders, No. 127, headquar-
ters. Department of Southern Luzon, Manila, Philippine Is-
lands. August 17, 1900, is remitted.

2. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Private
Benjamin F. Childers, Troop C, 4th Cavalry, Manila, Philip-
pine Islands, will be discharged from the Army, by way of
favor, by the commanding officer of his station. This soldier
is not entitled to travel-pay.

3. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, paragraph
9, Special Orders, No. 232, October 3, 1900, from this office,
relating to Commissary Sergeant Loring A. Bond, Camp
McKinley, Hawaiian Islands, is revoked.

4. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, so much of
paragraph 1, Special Orders, No. 263. November 8, 1900, from
this office, as relates to Ordnance Sergeant George F. W. Miller,
U. S. Army is amended to read, “Sergeant George F. W. Miller,
ordnance detachment.”

5. Private Patrick Hughes, Battery G, 2d Artillery, Havana,
Cuba, is transferred to Troop K, 7th Cavalry, stationed at
that place, and will report to the commanding officer thereof
for duty. The expenses of the transfer, if any, will be borne
by the soldier.

6. The following-named enlisted men, now in this city, hav-
ing performed the duties assigned them in paragraph 1,
Special Orders, No. 230, Fort Thomas, Kentucky, November
8, 1900, will return to that station:

Corporal William J. Schuck, Company C, 2d Infantry, with
permission to delay five days en route;

Musician Adolph H. Scharnowske, Company B, 2d Infantry,
with permission to delay twelve days en route.

The Quartermaster's Department will furnish the necessary
transportation.

7. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, the follow-
ing-named enlisted men of the Hospital Corps, now at the
Army General Hospital, Washington Barracks, District of
Columbia, are detailed as acting hospital stewards, assigned
to duty at and will be sent to the stations designated after
their respective names:
Private Joseph C. Read, to Fort Monroe, Virginia;
Private John Praneuf, to Fort Wayne, Michigan;
Private August A. Bemtgen, to Fort Morgan, Alabama.

They will report upon arrival to their respective command-
ing officers for duty.

8. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, the follow-
ing-named enlisted men of the Hospital Corps, now at the
stations designated after their respective names, are detailed
as acting hospital stewards and assigned to duty at their pres-
ent stations:
Private Bruno T. O. Hoffman, West Point, New York;
Private Robert A. Dickson, Jefferson Barracks, Missouri.

9. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, the follow-
ing-named medical officers are detailed to represent the Medi-
cal Department of the Army at the Pan-American Medical
Congress to meet in the city of Havana, Cuba, December 26 to
29, 1900:
Major Valery Havard, surgeon, U. S. Army; ✓
Major William C. Gorgas, surgeon, U. S. Army; ✓
Major Jefferson R. Kean, surgeon, U. S. Volunteers. ✓

10. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War. Captain
Richmond McA. Schofield, assistant quartermaster, U. S.
Army (recently appointed from 1st lieutenant, 5th U. S. Cav-
alry), will proceed without delay to San Francisco. Califor-
nia, and report in person to the general superintendent of the
Army transport service at that place for assignment to duty
as quartermaster and acting commissary of subsistence on
the transport “Meade” to relieve Captain Harry L. Pettus,
assistant quartermaster, U. S. Volunteers, of those duties.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

11. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Electrician
Sergeant Lee J. Whitney, now at the Artillery School, Fort
Monroe, Virginia, is transferred to Fort Flagler, Washington.
He will be sent to that post and will report upon arrival to
the commanding officer for duty.

12. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, the follow-
ing-named electrician sergeants, appointed November 9, 1900,
now at the Artillery School, Fort Monroe, Virginia, will be
sent to the stations designated after their respective names:

Hardy S. Hammond (appointed from sergeant, Battery C,
2d Artillery), to Fort Du Pont Delaware;

Frank Doran (appointed from sergeant, Battery G, 1st Ar-
tillery), to Fort Strong, Massachusetts;

Orville K. McCombs (appointed from corporal, Battery N,
4th Artillery), to Fort Screven, Georgia;

appointment and duty as aid-de-camp on his staff. The travel
enjoined is necessary for the public service.

20. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, paragraph
10, Special Orders, No. 258. November 2, 1900, from this office,
is so amended as to direct Major Lawrence C. Carr, surgeon,
U. S. Volunteers, upon his relief from duty in the Division of
Cuba, to proceed via Havana, Cuba, to this city and report in
person to the Surgeon General of the Army for instructions.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

21. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Acting
Assistant Surgeon John S. Fogg, U. S. Army, will proceed
from Biddeford, Maine, to Fort McHenry, Maryland, and re-
port in person to the commanding officer of that post for tem-
porary duty, and by letter to the commanding general, De-
partment of the East. The travel enjoined is necessary for
the public service.

22. By direction of the President, Major Rafael Echeverria, ✓
surgeon, U. S. Volunteers, is honorably discharged from the
service of the United States by the Acting Secretary of War,
to take effect November 30, 1900, his services being no longer
required.

23. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, the exten-
sion of leave of absence on account of sickness granted 1st
Lieutenant Herman C. Schumm, 2d U. S. Artillery, in Special
Orders, No. 158, July 7, 1900, from this office, is further ex-
tended ten days on account of sickness.

24. The leave of absence on surgeon's certificate of disability
granted 1st Lieutenant Lucius R. Holbrook, 1st U. S. Cavalry,
in Special Orders, No. 230, October 15, 1900, Department of
California, is extended two months on account of sickness.

25. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Captain Silas
A. Wolf, 4th U. S. Infantry, is relieved from recruiting duty in
Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, and will proceed to and take sta-
tion at Newark, New Jersey, and relieve Captain William P.
Van Ness, 1st U. S. Artillery, and 1st Lieutenant James F.
Brady, 7th U. S. Artillery, from recruiting duty in that city.
Lieutenant Brady upon being thus relieved will rejoin his
proper recruiting station. The travel enjoined is necessary
for the public service.
BY COMMAND OF LIEUTENANT GENERAL MILES:

H. C. CORBIN,
Adjutant General.
